etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Charles Wheatstone (1802–1875), developer of telegraphy. From rheo- + -scope

definitions: An instrument for detecting the existence of an electric current; a means of detecting a current.

notes.text: In Wheatstone's nomenclature the rheoscope differed from "rheometer" by merely detecting a current, rather than detecting and measuring it.

definitions: An instrument for observing the effects of shear on particles, especially red blood cells.
